content:
Hi, I am a mathematics student learning about automated reasoning and control theory and I am learning Lean, concentrating on formalizing mathematical proofs.

I want to ask if, in the mathlib4, Lyapunov's second method for stability is formalized.

Thanks.
You'll get an answer faster, if you provide a link a description of the method you're talking about.
The answer is probably "no" but it may be "no, and it will need months to get there" or "no, but you can do it in under a week".

Thank you for your comments. I think this method is also known as Lyapunov's direct method, which states in here: https://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/handle/1721.1/74611/6-241-fall-2003/contents/recitations/rec6.pdf
Lyapunov stability and Lyapunov theorem (if there is a Lyapunov function, then there is Lyapunov stability) aren't in Mathlib but can be added in a week or two.
Bach Hoang has marked this topic as resolved.

More precisely: I can formalize both in a day. To add both to Mathlib, we need to agree on the right generality first, and this can take time (there are ODEs, iterations of a map, and monoid actions; there are fixed points and periodic orbits, probably more variations).
